newsitem.title: USA: Ford Q3 net meets Wall Street forecasts.
newsitem.headline: Ford Q3 net meets Wall Street forecasts.

text.p: Ford Motor Co's third quarter net profit of $686 million, or $0.56 a share, was in line with Wall Street expectations, but analysts noted concern about losses in Ford's overseas automotive businesses.

Excluding a net gain of $37 million or $0.03 a share from asset sales by Ford's USL Capital unit, Ford earned $649 million, or $0.53 a share. First Call Corp.'s consensus estimate for the automaker was $0.52 a share, excluding extraordinary items.
Ford shares were off 1/2 to 32-3/4 in early trading.
Ford's earnings for the July-September period rose 92 percent from year-earlier profits of $357 million, or $0.27 a share, but much of the increase came from financial services, not cars and trucks.

Ford's Financial Services Group earned a record $671 million despite a 16.2 percent drop in Ford Motor Credit Co's earnings to $299 million from $357 million. In the third quarter of 1995, Financial Services earned $558 million.
Ford's automotive operations, hurt by losses in Europe and South America, earned just $15 million, compared with a year earlier loss of $201 million.

But third quarter losses in Europe widened to $472 million from $320 million a year ago, while losses in South America, mostly in Brazil, increased to $226 million from $102 million in the 1995 period.
"I think there's some real red flags there with overseas operations and Ford Credit," said Bear Stearns auto analyst Nicholas Lobocarro. "I would have expected to see better results in Europe."

The third quarter is typically the weakest of the year, but General Motors Corp said Tuesday that it earned a $75 million profit in Europe in the third quarter, compared with a year-earlier loss of $98 million. GM's international operations earned a $323 million profit for the quarter, up from $111 million a year earlier.

Both GM and Chrysler Corp soundly exceeded Wall Street estimates. Chrysler nearly doubled its earnings to $680 million, or $0.93 a share, while GM's profits from continuing operations more than tripled to $1.3 billion, or $1.57 a share.

Ford's U.S. automotive operations earned a third-quarter record of $634 million, up from $187 million a year ago. However, Lobocarro said he was not confident of Ford's ability to sustain strong U.S. automotive earnings in a weaker market.
